p.s: In order to intensify and illustrate his view on how paradox the nature of love is, the author makes use of many formal and poetic devices.
The sonnet follows its strict demands for Shakespearean sonnets with its 14 lines divided into three quatrains and a concluding heroic couplet at the end, which (typically) includes the moral.
The rhyme scheme is abab cdcd efef gg (cross rhyme and couple rhyme).
The metric follows an iambic pentameter, which symbolizes the rhytmrhythm of a heartbeat and is therefore the perfect fit for the topic of love and gives the sonnet a very emotional atmosphere.
It also underlines that the sonnet is meant to be presented, because the iambic pentameter is the metric utilized the most in everyday englishEnglish and therefore gives life to the poem.
In line nine there is a voltaVolta, which is signalized by the word but.
In line one the author employs the metaphor made of truth.
This symbolizes not only the desperate attempt of trying to uphold the lies the couple created, but also illustrates how unrealistic it is for someone to be 100% truthful.
A person who has never lied simply does not exist.
This metaphor helps the reader to visually imagine such person and adds a tragic element to the poem, which is underscored by the verb swears in the beginning of line one.
Therefore, the antithesis I do believe her, though she lies in line two intensifies the paradox nature of this relationship and to an extend love in general.
The person his or her beloved claims to be can notcannot ever eist in real life, so why does he believe her so easily?
The reader is now torn between the perfect image that the beloved created and the harsh truth the speaker knows of.

The metaphor her false speaking tongue in line seven establishes an image of being tongue tiedtongue-tied and therefore almost helpless, as if the beloved would not have any control over what she says.
The speaker simply persuades himself that it is her tongue that is untruthful, but never actually the beloved.

In this case one does not speak of a poetic conceit, but of a tragic flaw that in the case of the couple emerges in their inability to be truthful to one another and this their ability to uphold the created conceit.
The word O in line eleven adds tragedy to the poem.
It sounds like a sigh and vocalizes the drama in his thesis (love's best habit is in seeming trust, line 11).
Thus it sounds more alive and awakens a tragic feeling in the listener.

The parallelism Therefore I lie with her, and she with me gives the poem not only a round ending, but also shows the listener the couple's willing acceptance of this viscious circle both are trapped in, but do not want to break free from.
They might make these mistakes forever, but they will always be together, because of their acceptance of each other's tragic flaw.
It saves and ruins them all at once.
The listener may feel as though the speaker has exposed them, or given a voice to something they can notcannot put into words.

All in all, one can say that the author conveyed his message through very imaginitaveimaginative language, with the help of metaphors, in order to describe a feeling and the paradox nature of something many struggle to voice.
